Comment: This game was a battle.  I had to use all of my chess knowledge to beat this fine opponent.  It was also a team match and I played stronger to not let my team down.  I opened with the Sicilian which is my favorite opening for black.
I wanted to open with the familiar d6 but I wanted to throw my opponent off just a bit.
I wanted to open with the familiar d6 but I wanted to throw my opponent off just a bit.
I wanted to open with the familiar d6 but I wanted to throw my opponent off just a bit.
My opponent surprised me as I was expecting the typical 3.d4 exd4 4.Nxd4
In the Sicilian it is typical to bring the c-knight out first to control d4
He foregoes castling to develop his c-knight.
I develop a second knight and am not worried about 5. e5 because Ng4 wins the pawn.
White is attempting to control d5 so I counter with cxd4
It took me a long time to understand why the small center is important in the Sicilian.  6..d6 prevents 7.Bf4 allowing me to keep control of e5
It took me a long time to understand why the small center is important in the Sicilian.  6..d6 prevents 7.Bf4 allowing me to keep control of e5
It took me a long time to understand why the small center is important in the Sicilian.  6..d6 prevents 7.Bf4 allowing me to keep control of e5
White takes my knight moving it twice before castling.  I still have good pawn structure when I take back even though the c6 pawn is undefended.
unpinning the knight and preparing for kingside castling
unpinning the knight and preparing for kingside castling
unpinning the knight and preparing for kingside castling
notice that white compromises his kingside pawn structure for a fruitless attack.  He wants 10. e5 dxe5 11.Qxd8+ Kxd8 so I cant castle.  I ignore his subtle threat and castle
Whites plan is to castle queenside and pawn storm my castled position.  He is also indirectly attacking my undefended c6 pawn on the next move.
Whites plan is to castle queenside and pawn storm my castled position.  He is also indirectly attacking my undefended c6 pawn on the next move.
I now protect the c6 pawn with my bishop and I dont have to worry about 11.e5
As expected white castles queenside
11..Ne8?  A risky move on my part but the plan was to keep d6 defended and force an exchange of dark squared bishops.
White immediately goes to attacking my castled position.  Notice my knight is not on its ideal square of f6
White immediately goes to attacking my castled position.  Notice my knight is not on its ideal square of f6
White immediately goes to attacking my castled position.  Notice my knight is not on its ideal square of f6
H6 was probably a mistake.  Better was a5 attacking his castled position.  Now white is going to shred my kingside position with g4!
14..Kh8?  15. g4! Kh7 but this did not happen as white goes in for the kill with Bd3!
14..Kh8?  15. g4! Kh7 but this did not happen as white goes in for the kill with Bd3!
Im fighting for my life here as I try to block the d3- h7 diagonal.

16. g5! Now I have to place my king on the aforementioned diagonal because 17.gxh6 gxh6  18. Qxh6+ Kg8
